message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest community-acquired pneumonia, and the most common etiologic agent of community-acquired pneumonia is Streptococcus pneumoniae.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, physical examination findings, and radiographic findings suggest community-acquired pneumonia. Among the options, Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common causative agent of community-acquired pneumonia. Legionella pneumophila is associated with severe pneumonia and is more commonly found in immunocompromised patients. Haemophilus influenzae is associated with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) exacerbations. Mycoplasma pneumoniae is associated with atypical pneumonia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s presentation suggests community-acquired pneumonia, and among the options, Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common cause of community-acquired pneumonia. Legionella pneumophila often presents with multi-organ involvement and is associated with contaminated water sources. Haemophilus influenzae is a common cause of pneumonia in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Mycoplasma pneumoniae is associated with atypical pneumonia, which usually presents with a milder course of illness.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and signs described suggest a diagnosis of community-acquired pneumonia (CAP), which is most commonly caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae. Legionella pneumophila is more commonly associated with atypical pneumonia, and Haemophilus influenzae is less common in healthy adults. Mycoplasma pneumonia is also a common cause of atypical pneumonia, but the described lung findings are more suggestive of CAP.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination suggest pneumonia and the most common etiologic agent is Streptococcus pneumoniae. Legionella pneumophila is associated with high mortality rates and is usually seen in immunocompromised patients, smokers or those with underlying lung diseases. Haemophilus influenzae and Mycoplasma pneumoniae are also common etiologic agents of pneumonia, but not as common as Streptococcus pneumoniae.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and radiographic findings suggest community-acquired pneumonia, and among the options, Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common cause of this type of pneumonia. Other options such as Legionella pneumophila and Haemophilus influenzae can also cause community-acquired pneumonia, but they are less common. Mycoplasma pneumoniae is usually associated with atypical pneumonia. Smoking history is a risk factor for developing pneumonia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical exam findings are consistent with lobar pneumonia, and Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common etiologic agent for community-acquired pneumonia. Legionella pneumophila is more commonly associated with atypical, interstitial pneumonia. Haemophilus influenzae is a less common cause of community-acquired pneumonia, and Mycoplasma pneumoniae typically presents with a more gradual onset and is associated with a non-productive cough.

The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest community-acquired pneumonia, and the most common etiologic agent in this case is Streptococcus pneumoniae. Legionella pneumophila is associated with outbreaks and clusters and is less common in single cases. Haemophilus influenzae is a common cause of pneumonia in COPD patients and Mycoplasma pneumoniae typically presents with a nonproductive cough.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest community-acquired pneumonia in the right upper lobe. Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common etiologic agent of community-acquired pneumonia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest community-acquired pneumonia, and the most common etiologic agent is Streptococcus pneumoniae. Legionella pneumophila is more commonly associated with atypical pneumonia, and Haemophilus influenzae is less common. Mycoplasma pneumonia can also cause community-acquired pneumonia, but it typically presents with a more gradual onset of symptoms.
